Unlike absorption, where a liquid is dissolved into another liquid or solid, adsorption occurs when a solid grabs and holds onto other molecules within a liquid solution. We use biochar as an adsorbent in the lab because it tends to do a good job of grabbing onto these other molecules.

The adsorption tests I perform are used to see how changing different factors affects the effectiveness of biochar as an adsorbent. I use a solution containing a known amount of copper ions as the molecules to be adsorbed by the biochar, and most of my tests are performed on either the shake table or rotary mixer. By varying mass of biochar used, mixing time, and intensity of mixing, we can see how well the biochar interacts with the copper ions under different circumstances.
-Alyssa

Most of the research I do focuses on biochar. You can think of biochar almost like homemade charcoal. We take any organic material (such as pinecone or hemp fiber), break it down into smaller pieces, and place it in a furnace. Since the martial has to get really hot to form biochar, we flow nitrogen or argon into the furnace to create a lack of oxygen and keep the material from ashing or catching on fire. The result is a black, almost powdery substance that we can use to perform many adsorption experiments.
-Alyssa

Elkhorn was defined by one large mine near the town, but there were many smaller mines in the the nearby mountains. Most of the artifacts at these mines have been stripped by scrappers, desperate miners, and plain selfish souvenir hunters. There are still a few though that have some historic remnants left. One of the most interesting things I've seen out here is this old whim. It has mostly rotted away, but the drum still remains. It was built like a barrel, and rope would have been wrapped around it. A horse (or other strong animal) would be connected to an arm and would be directed to walk in a circle. As the drum spun, the rope would wind around it, lifting a bucket full of rock out of the nearby shaft.
Gabe

One of the main projects I have been working on here at East Boulder mine is gathering data using the Hovermap. This cool machine takes over 300,000 shots per second and allow us to easily and efficiently map the headings and ramps in the mine. Once I gathered the data from underground, I download the information as and create solids from the gathered points. We use a variety of software including Deswik, Vulcan, and PointStudio. I have also worked on making Tunnel Asbuilts for the data that we have in our system and included a list of the difference solids I’ve made for a variety of ramps and footwalls.

May 18 at 7:14 PM ·

Eye in the sky drone video for the Ground Water Investigation Program’s (GWIP) East Flathead Project near Kalispell. GWIP hydrologists Jim Berglund and Dean Snyder, along with new Montana Tech graduate student John Allard, conduct stream flow surveys along the Swan Range to measure meltwater runoff and to estimate groundwater recharge into the valley’s aquifers. With this information, along with well level measurements, the East Flathead team will create a groundwater model to assess future water use scenarios for the region. Drone footage and video by Jim Berglund. For more information about the project contact project lead Andy Bobst abobst@mtech.edu

I know I mentioned the other day that I spend my days and nights either managing the MBMG Data Center (https://mbmg.mtech.edu/datacenter) or making sure I have enough content either recorded or posted online, emails and messages from students replied to, etc. So, this morning I thought I would highlight both my campus and home command centers. Diggers rise to meet and overcome challenges because it's who we are.

The move to completely online course delivery has been a challenge to be sure. My Technical Writing students are participating in a "One Room Virtual Schoolhouse" in a Facebook group since we are learning about how social media supports Technical Writing principles. My Database Designers are working on a Museum Information Management System. I'm excited to see what the finish line brings!

Have an awesome day!

Congratulations to our Health and Safety Manager, Tara Schleeman, for passing her Certified Instructional Trainer (CIT) exam! The CIT is earned by individuals with expertise and experience in developing, designing, and delivering safety, health and environmental (SH&E) training. Tara already possessed the Certified Safety Professional (CSP) certification and with this new certification, she is well on her way to making Pioneer even more safe than we already are! We #BelieveInZero and Tara’s commitment to excellence and safety on the job is just another way that Pioneer makes a difference!
